aliens.wildBody: When another player collects compensation, after they have taken the card(s) but before they add them to their hand, add this card to those cards, and shuffle them. Draw two of them at random, and return any remaining cards to that player.
aliens.superBody: When using your power, you may extract two players' ships from the targeted planet, sending them to the same planet.

aliens.name: Force
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Interlope.
aliens.powerBody: If you are not a main player or ally, after encounter cards are selectd and before they are revealed, you may use this power to choose a main player. Look at the chosen player's encounter card. You may swap that card with one from your hand (that player may look at the swapped card). If you swapped cards and that player wins the encounter or makes a deal, gain three rewards. If that player loses the encounter or fails to make a deal, send two of your ships from your colonies to the warp, and that player gains one reward.
aliens.history: At first glance, a Force appears to be yet another mystical entity, but nothing could be further from the truth as their tomfoolery and hijinks lead them to ridiculous, improbably situations. From their questionable "Two-Card Monte" to their dubious "Truth Simulator," who knows what they'll get up to next.
aliens.wildBody: During launch, you may give a card to a main player. If that card is played or revealed during this encounter, you and that player each gain two rewards. Otherwise, you must send one of your ships to the warp.
aliens.superBody: You may use your power as an ally.

aliens.name: Geek
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Esoterica.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, after the defense is determined, use this power to force your opponent to secretly draw a random unused alien. If they drew an alien with Game Setup text, or one that is not allowed in the game, they remove that alien from the game and draw again. Then, that player reads aloud its short power description (the upside-down text at the top of the sheet). If you correctly guess the alien's name in one attempt, you either gain the sheet under your control as your "buddy" or discard it. If your guess is incorrect, your opponent chooses to either give it to you as your buddy, or discard it.

You use the power of your buddy in addition to your own power. Before you would gain a second buddy, remove your current buddy from the game.
aliens.history: Taking their love of the Cosmos to an uncool degree, the physically unremarkable Geeks huddle together in the safety of their interests. They have studies the nuances of every known alien species, desperate to find weakness, desperate to perhaps be more like them, but mostly just desperate.
aliens.wildBody: If another player would win the game, say aloud the name of a card that would change the outcome. If any player has it, they give it to you. Otherwise, you have 30 seconds to find it. If you are given or find the card, play it.
aliens.superBody: Before you gain a buddy, play this card to keep up to five buddies at one time. If you lose this card, choose one buddy to keep and remove the rest.

aliens.name: Gremlin
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Meddle.
aliens.powerBody:
At the start of each player's turn, draw a hazard card from the hazard deck (even if the Hazard Deck variant is not being used) and place it facedown on this sheet.

At the end of the destiny phase, if no hazard warnings were drawn during this encounter, you may use this power to play a hazard card from this sheet. Before the hazard deck discard pile is shuffled to reform the hazard deck, discard all hazard cards on this sheet.
aliens.history: Gremlins can never leave well-enough alone. They exist in a culture that rewards interference, trespassing, and insubordination. While other aliens may attempt to live in peace, the Gremlins remind them that trouble is always brewing.
aliens.wildBody: After your color is drawn from destiny, if you are not the offense, force the offense to discard their hand, draw a new one, and continue their turn.
aliens.superBody: As the offense, if a hazard warning was drawn, draw a hazard card and place it on your sheet. Then, you can use your power (even though a hazard warning was drawn).

aliens.name: Guardian
aliens.short: Ships Are Worth More as Ally
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Guard.
aliens.powerBody: As an ally, after encounter cards are revealed, use this power to change the value of your ships for encounter totals. Each of your ships is worth the number of ships that the main player on your side has in the encounter. For example, if the main player on your side has three ships in the encounter, each of your ships is worth three for encounter totals.
aliens.history: Selfless guards, the Guardians are dedicated to the preservation of those they serve. Leaving their own interests unguarded, the Guardians put every effort into the victory of their allies. Perhaps they are mindless thugs, as their detractors describe them. Yet, it is hard to claim and their lack of a brain is preventing them from crafting a cunning plan.
aliens.wildBody: As an ally, increase the value of the attack card revealed by the main player on your side by 4.
aliens.superBody: As a main player, each of your ships is worth thrice the number of allies on your side. For example, if you had three allies, each of your ships is worth nine for encounter totals.

aliens.name: Hurtz
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Lease.
aliens.powerBody:
Either before or after encounter cards are revealed (but not both), you may use this power to make an "offer to lease" your ships to each player in the encounter. For each player that agrees (heretofore the "lessee"), take a number of your ships from any of your colonies not involved in the encounter up to the number of ships that the lessee had in the encounter and stackthose ships under the lessee's ships. Then, place one token on this sheet, or two if the lease is made after encounter cards are revealed.

A lessee's ships are treated as their own ships and are worth two for encounter totals and rewards. However, leased ships cannot move unless they move with an equal number of non-leased ships from the same stack. If leased ships no longer have a non-leased ship above them, or if the lessee no longer controls the leased ships for any reason, they return to your colonies (regardless of other game effects).

Once per encounter, at any time, you may discard a token from their sheet to either cancel the lease on all leased ships for one lessee (returning them to your colonies) or to double the number of rewards you gain as a successful defensive ally.
aliens.history: When ships are in short supply, the enterprising Hurtz are happy to help with a handy off-planet stash. "We put you in the pilot's seat." For a modest fee, of course.
aliens.wildBody: Offer to lease your alien power to another player for the remainder of the encounter. If they agree, they can use your power instead of their own and you cannot use your own power (or their power). If that player is on the winning side, take two cards at random from that player. Otherwise, take only one card.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, gain three tokens (instead of one or two).

aliens.name: Inferno
aliens.gameSetup: Shuffle the additional five copies of the Inferno flare into the cosmic deck after hands are dealt.
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Flare.
aliens.powerBody:
After another player plays a flare and attempts to return it to their hand, you may use this power to take it instead.

When you have no encounter cards and would discard your hand to draw a new one, reveal any flares in your hand, and set them aside. Draw your new hand, and then add the set-aside flares to your hand.
aliens.history: Expelled from the fiery depths of a red giant star, the Inferno defiled the cold wastes of space. They sought out other sources of heat to burn, increasing their power with each flare up. Nothing will satisfy the Inferno until the entire Cosmos is consumed in an ultimate conflagration.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player or ally, each player on your side may discard a flare from their hand. The first discarded flare adds 20 to your side's total and each flare after that adds 10. If at least one player discarded a flare, give this Inferno flare to the Inferno or discard it if the Inferno is not playing.
aliens.superBody: Return this card to your hand. Then if you have five flares in your hand, two of which are Inferno flares, you win the game.

aliens.name: Insect
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Metamorphosis.
aliens.powerBody:
After a player plays and resolves a flare, you may use this power to either discard a flare from your hand of an alien not in game or, if you have no such flares in your hand, draw and discard a flare from the unused flare deck. If that alien does not have Game Setup text and is allowed in the game, gain their sheet under your control as "new flesh."

You use the power of your new flesh in addition to your own power. Before you would gain new flesh, remove your older flesh from the game.
aliens.history: The short-lived Insects rapidly adapt to match the strengths of any opponent. They believe that their ability to metamorphose and copy any ecological innovation will lead to ultimate control of the Cosmos.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, after you lose an encounter, discard your hand and draw a new one. (Return this card to your hand.)
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, you can choose to draw and discard a flare from the unused flare deck even if you have a flare in your hand.

aliens.name: Lemming
aliens.short: Gains Colonies From Ships in the Warp
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Migrate.
aliens.powerBody: After the defense is determined, if you have nine or more ships in the warp, you may use this power to move four of your ships out of the warp onto any planet in the defense's system where you do not have a foreign colony.
aliens.history: The small, odd-looking Lemmings are known for their mass migrations, especially those resulting in self-sacrifice. What is not well known about the Lemmings is their unusual ability to turn up in unexpected places, seemingly out of nowhere. The connection between these points is not well understood, noot even by scholars.
aliens.wildBody: During your regroup phase, when you retrieve a ship from the warp, you may place it on any planet where all players have a colony except for you and the planet's owner.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, you can move one to three ships from the warp (instead of four).

aliens.name: Lloyd
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Insure.
aliens.powerBody:
At any time, you may use this power to "offer to insure" any or all of the following assets of another player until the end of the encounter: alien powers (before they are used), ships (before they are lost or captured), and specifically named cards (before they are played, discarded or taken). Insured cards must be named explicitly (e.g. attack 30, Cosmic Zap). If your offer is accepted, place a token on this sheet.

Insured alien powers cannot be lost or cancelled. Insured ships are returned to colonies instead of being lost or captured. Insured cards cannot be forcibly discarded, taken, or collected as compensation. An insured card cannot be played more than once in the encounter.

At any time, you may spend a token to gain a reward.
aliens.history: The Lloyd have been known to generations as protectors. Although they should have learned their lesson by trusting Nobody, the Lloyd still always uphold any contract.
aliens.wildBody: When you would lose a colony, one of the ships that would have been lost or captured remains on the planet instead.
aliens.superBody: Once per encounter, if a player of your choice agrees to it, you may use your power to insure one card in your hand or your ships in the encounter. That player may gain one reward for agreeing.

aliens.name: Magnet
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Attract or Repel.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player or an ally, after alliances are formed, you may use this power to force one offensive ally to become a defensive ally, or vice versa. You cannot use this power to choose yourself.

As a main player or ally, after alliances are formed, if you did not use the previous power, you may use this power to force one player in the encounter to match the same number of ships that you have in the encounter by moving ships to or from their colonies, as appropriate.
aliens.history: Originating on a highly ferrous planetoid, the Magnets thrived on the intense fields generated at its poles. Soon they achieved the ability to manipulate and reverse energy fields by group induction, and are now attempting to use their magnetic personalities to attract (and repel) all they meet.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, before cards are selected, name one encounter card. Your opponent cannot select that card unless they have no other encounter cards (for example: attack 20).
aliens.superBody: During this encounter, you can use both power in either order.

aliens.name: Negator
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Negate.
aliens.powerBody: Once per encounter, you may use this power to play a negation from your essence card cache on another player as per the timing on the negation.
aliens.history: The Null and Void were worshiped are the twin gods of the Negators. Whenever another being attempts a positive action, Negators are compelled to counteract it and deny its existence. Experiencing kinship with all that is negative and disdain for all that is not negative, the apathy and generally undefined attitude of the Null being their undoing when the Negators and the Hate joined forces to subtract their former idols from the Cosmos.
aliens.wildBody: If you are a main player, after cards are revealed, all revealed attack cards with a positive value have a negative value instead (e.g., a 10 becomes a -10). Then, give this card to the Negator or discard it if the Negator is not playing.
aliens.superBody: You may use your power twice per encounter.

aliens.name: Phantom
aliens.gameSetup: Place one ship from each of your planets on this sheet.
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Materialize.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, after cards are revealed, use this power to add two to your encounter total for each of your ships on this sheet. Your ships in this encounter do not add to your encounter total but do count for compensation and rewards normally.

When your ships would return to colonies, you may place one or more of them on this sheet instead. When you would move ships from your colonies or choose ships for other effects, you may use ships from this sheet. If this sheet is lost or turned facedown, ships on it are returned to your colonies.
aliens.history: The origin of the Phantoms remains a mystery, but all that could be said of their first appearance was: "Alas, poor Spheric. They fell victim to the night." The Phantoms' motives and social structure are unclear, but people come out in droves to witness them.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, after encounter cards are revealed, place up to four ships from your colonies on either the hyperspace gate or the targeted planet, as appropriate. (This can cause you to be above your normal limit.)
aliens.superBody: You can use your power as an ally

aliens.name: Silencer
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Silence.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, after destiny is drawn, you may use this power to place one silence token, total silence side faceup, on the sheet of any player who does not have a silence token. When a player with a silence token speaks, invites allies, accepts alliances, or uses optional powers, they are penalized for being "too noisy." Penalize them either by sending any one of their ships not in the encounter to the warp or by forcing them to discard a card at random from their hand.

If a player has a total silence token, at the end of the encounter, they flip it to its partial silence side. If a player has a partial silence token, after they are penalized, they return that token to your supply.
aliens.history: The antediluvian Silencers long dwelt in a state of pure meditation. Aghasty at the chaotic proliferation of verbose - some grandiloquent, other time garrulous - life forms, they feel a holy duty to bring the virtue of quietude back to the Cosmos.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, cancel the use of your opponent's power. This is not treated as a cosmic zap. Your opponent's power cannot be used for the rest of the encounter. Then, give this card to the Silencer or discard it if the Silencer is not in the game.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, flip one or two partial silence tokens to the total silence side.

aliens.name: Tentacle
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Appendages.
aliens.powerBody: As a main player or ally, after encounter cards are revealed, use this power. Choose one revealed encounter card that has a numerical value (including a morph). Add each of the value's digits to that side's total. For example, if you reveal an attack 15, add 1 and 5 to the card's value for a total of 21.
aliens.history: Swirling masses of flexible appendages, filaments, and processes, the uncanny Tentacles always seem to reach into every corner of the Cosmos. Just when you think you have a handle on them, the Tentacles have another sucker-bearing tendril up their proverbial sleeves, ready to envelop, engulf, or merely obfuscate.
aliens.wildBody: When you would gain rewards or collected compensation, discard a reinforcement to gain or collect its value in additional rewards or compensation, as appropriate.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, add the digits of both revealed encounter cards to one side's encounter total (instead of just one of the encounter cards).

aliens.name: The Meek
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Yield.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, when you lose the encounter, use this power to advance your colony marker. Failing to make a deal is not treated as a loss.

As a main player, when you win the encounter, use this power to move your colony marker back. Your colony marker cannot go below zero. Making a successful deal is not treated as a win. (You still win the game when your colony marker reaches 5.)

You do not lose your power due to too few home colonies.
aliens.history: Brainwashed by centuries of being told how they would inherit all they survey, the Meek have tirelessly adhered to a strict practice of submission, compliance, and gentleness. If all goes to prophecy, their ultimate gain will be well worth the suffering.
aliens.wildBody: As a losing ally, collect compensation from the opposing main player.
aliens.superBody: As the offense, if you lost your first encounter, have a second encounter.

aliens.name: Throwback
aliens.powerName: You have the power of anarchronism.
aliens.powerBody:
Whenever you draw a hand, including your starting hand, draw seven cards instead of eight.

When speaking, you should refer to colonies as bases, ships as tokens, encounters as challenges, encounter cards as challenge cards, artifacts as edicts, negotiate cards as compromise cards, compensation as consolation, and the hyperspace gate as the cone. When other players use the modern terms, you may this power to receive one reward when you correct another player in this way.

At any time, you may use this power to purge from your hand one or more modern cards having: a card type other than Attack, Compromise (Negotiate), Flare, Edict (Artifact), or kicker; a cardback not matching the cosmic deck; or an Attack value other than 01, 04-10, 12-18, 20, 30 or 40. You may discard them and draw an equal number of cards; give these cards to another player; or trade these cards to other players (if willing) for anything they could give you as part of a deal.

You may play any number of flares per challenge, even playing the same flare more than once if the context for playing it comes up more than once.
aliens.history: Ever reminiscing about the "good old times," the Throwback prefer things to work as they once did. Although they romanticize the past as unquestionably superior, they nonetheless also exploit the blessings of modern life. This apparent cognitive dissonance gives way to caprice as the throwback choose to live in the past or the present, as befits the need of the moment.
aliens.wildBody: You may Un-Zap any Zap. Cancel the effect of any Cosmic Zap or Card Zap, a Flarezap (if you can find one), or any other "Zap" effect from an Edict (which you probably call an Artifact). Then discard this Flare, although the real Throwback can immediately snatch it from the discard pile. This Wild Flare cannot be Zapped.
aliens.superBody: Any time before the outcome of a challenge is final, you may declare that challenge to be "retro." All reinforcement cards played are worth zero, and any main player who revealed a Morph immediately loses the challenge.

aliens.name: Vector
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Direction.
aliens.powerBody: After you accept an invitation to become an ally, use this power to choose which side your vector token is faceup: either its normal or its reverse side. If the reverse side is faceup and your side of the encounter wins, you gain the effect of winning as though you had been on the other side of the encounter (i.e., landing on the planet if allies with the defense or receiving rewards if allied with the offense). If the normal side is faceup and your side of the encounter wins, you gain the normal effects of winning. This power overrides other effects that change what happens if you win.
aliens.history: The mutagenic conditions of the Vector solar system wrecked havoc on their communication capabilities, and as a result they have a reputation for confounding the expectations of their allies. The Vectors make their own demands when committing to alliances of convenience - taking resources when attacking, and demanding colonial presence when defending.
aliens.wildBody: When a player would collect compensation, that player takes cards from you instead of their opponent.
aliens.superBody: As an ally, choose allies on your side to gain the effect of your vector token's faceup side.

aliens.name: Witch
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Curse.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player or ally, after you lose an encounter, use this power to "curse" one or more opposing players. For each player, choose a curse from your essence card cache and place it faceup in from of them. You cannot curse a player who is already cursed.

During each regroup phase, each cursed player may place one of their ships from their colonies onto their curse card. After a curse card has a number of ships on it equal to the number on the card, all of those ships are sent to the warp and the curse is placed in your unavailable pile.
aliens.history: The Witches so concentrated their anger about life's injustices that their inner rage became a force they could project against others. Now they never seem quite as happy as when an ill turn of fate releases this power and they can curse their enemies.
aliens.wildBody: You can use your power even if you have fewer than the required number of home colonies.
aliens.superBody: You can use your power on cursed players. When you do, place the player's previous curse in your unavailable pile and send any ships on it to the warp.

aliens.name: Wrack
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Injure.
aliens.powerBody: As a main player or ally, after a player on the opposing side plays a card, use this power. That player must send one of their ships from any of their colonies to the warp.
aliens.history: Sadistic to a degree unparalleled in recorded annals, the miserable Wracks haven't a decent sharn in their claydorns. After generations of bullying local flora and fauna, they now dream of intimidating the universe.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, for the rest of the encounter, your opponent must send one of their ships from any of their colonies to the warp each time they use their power.
aliens.superBody: As a main player, after alliances are formed, offer your opponent a deal. If it is accepted, proceed to resolution. If it is rejected, send one of their ships on a colony to the warp and you may offer additional deals; you may offer a number of deals up to the number of ships you have in the encounter. If they reject all of your deals, the encounter ends as a loss for your side.

aliens.name: Zilch
aliens.short: Wins by Helping Another Player Win
aliens.gameSetup: Secretly choose a destiny card that matches a player color and does not have a hazard warning. Place it facedown on this sheet. That player is "ordained".
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Zilch.
aliens.powerBody:
Once per encounter, you may use this power to play a fate from your essence card cache.

If the ordained player wins the game alone, you win the game with them. If the ordained player would be part of a shared win that does not include you, you win by yourself instead.

You may still win the game via the normal method.
aliens.history: The Zilch have no history, as they exist outside of our concepts of time. For them, past, present, and future are the same.
aliens.wildBody: If another player has fewer foreign colonies than each of the other players, that player may establish a colony on any planet. Then, give this card to the Zilch or discard it if the Zilch is not in the game.
aliens.superBody: "Nullify" any card. If you nullify an encounter card, it is treated as an attack 00. Otherwise, the card has no effect for this encounter (and is discarded if it would be normally). Then, discard this card.

aliens.name: Brute
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Pressure.
aliens.powerBody:
As an ally, after alliances are formed, you may use this power to pressure one player on the opposing side. That player must either remove all of their ships from the encounter and return them to their colonies or allow you to look at a number of random cards in their hand up to the number of ships that they had in the encounter and take one card of your choice.

If all of a main player's ships are removed, they continue the encounter with zero ships. If all of an ally's ships are removed, they are no longer an ally.
aliens.history: What the brutes lack in hostility, they make up for in immensity. They tend to gardens with blunt, careful hands where they can use their strength and massive frames to displace any soils in their way. Although other aliens often feel coerced after interacting with the Brutes, this usually stems from floriographic miscommunication rather than actual mallice.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player or ally, before compensation or rewards are gained, you may reduce each player's compensation and rewards to one.
aliens.superBody: You may use your power as a main player

aliens.name: Daredevil
aliens.short: Plays with Fire to Gain Rewards
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Peril.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player or ally, after encounter cards have been revealed, you may use this power to discard one attack card from your hand. Substract its value from your side's total.

As a main player or ally, after your side wins the encounter by 5 or less, each player on your side receives rewards equal to the number of ships they have in the encounter (in addition to any other benefits receives for winning).
aliens.history: Preferring an unpredictable and exhilaratng existence to certainty, Daredevils are addicted to adrenaline. Risk augments the Daredevil's abilities, and their allies either ramp up or blow up. For Daredevils, the closer the shave, the bigger rush - and they have the scars to prove it.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player or an ally, after encounter cards are selected but before they are revealed, you may play this card. If your side wins by 4 or less, use one of your ships in the encounter to establish a colony in the opposing main player's system. Otherwise, lose three ships in the warp.
aliens.superBody: You cause the players on your side to receive rewards if you win by 7 or less (instead of by 5 or less).

aliens.name: Demon
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Dominate.
aliens.powerBody:
If you are not a main player or ally, after encounter cards are selected but before they are revealed, you may use this power to discard an attack card from your hand. After encounter cards are revealed, if your card is lower than both revealed attack cards, each main player sends one of your ships to the warp from any of your colonies. If your card is higher than a main player's attack card, you may "dominate" ships of that player's allies. After the outcome is determined, you may take up to four of your ships from one of your colonies and use them to replace any of those allies' ships in the encounter on a one-for-one basis before those ships land on the planet or their owners gain rewards. Dominated ships are captured and placed on this sheet. Then, the encounter is completed normally.

After you draw a new hand, send all ships on this sheet to the warp and gain one reward for each player whose ships were on this sheet.
aliens.history: The opportunistic Demons seek to sap the will to win out of any whom they encounter. The molten homeworlds of their original galaxy will be reclaimed in the name of vengance.
aliens.wildBody: When a player is about to take compensation from another player, you may force that player to take compensation from you instead, and then you take compensation from the original targeted player.
aliens.superBody: You can use your power as an ally. You cannot have more than your nomral limit of ships in the encounter after dominating ships.

aliens.name: Grumpus
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Grrr-ump.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, after you lose the encounter or fail to make a deal, use this power. Each player with a colony in your system must send one of their ships from your system to the warp (even if they just established that colony). If this causes a player to lose a colony you may establish a foreign colony on any planet in that player's home system.

You do not lose your power because of having too few home colonies.
aliens.history: A Grumpus is indeed a ponderous sourpuss. Most species prefer not to engage with the Grumpi, lest they be suckered into a loquacious haranguing about how the Cosmos was better back in their millennium. But be careful what you do while visiting a Grumpus home world; they cannot stand it when their visitors pay to much attention to their communication devices.
aliens.wildBody: After the hyperspace gate is aimed, send one ship from the targeted system to the warp.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, each player must send two ships to the warp (instead of one).

aliens.name: Locust
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Consume.
aliens.powerBody:
As the offense or an offensive ally, after you win the encounter, if the targeted planet has no ships on it other than the defense's ships, use this power to consume the planet. Remove the consumed planet from the game, place it on this sheet, and send all ships on the planet to the warp. Each of your allies may either land their ships on another planet of their choice in the targeted system or return those ships to their colonies. Your ships return to your colonies.

Each planet you have consumed counts as one foreign colony towards victory for you, even if this power is later lost or stolen. If this power is stolen, consumed planets do not transfer with it.
aliens.history: Every 170 years, Locusts pour out of parallel universes in massive swarms of ships, seeking out planets that they can completely ingest to meet the ever-growing energy needs of their people.
aliens.wildBody: At the start of the regroup phase, you may send four of your ships from your colonies to the warp to destroy a planet that is not in the Locust's home system, remove it from the game. Any ships on that planet are sent to the warp. Then, give this flare to the Locust or discard it if the Locust is not playing.
aliens.superBody: Use your power even if other players have ships on the targeted planet. Those ships return to their colonies.

aliens.name: Masochist
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Love Pain.
aliens.powerBody:
At the start of any player's regroup phase, before the offense retrieves a ship from the warp, use this power to win the game if you have lost all of your ships. Lost ships include those in the warp, those removed from the game, and those captured by other players. Your ships cannot be removed from the warp or prevented from going to the warp for any reason during the game.

You do not lose this power because of having too few home colonies, and you may still win the game via the normal manner.
aliens.history: The Masochists derive pleasure from experiences that others would describe as pain. However, some alien species suspect it's really a religious ritual to bring forth the Masochist's dominance in this universe.
aliens.wildBody: During the regroup phase, choose a player other than the offense. That player retrieves one ship from the warp instead of the offense. You cannot use this flare if the offense's ships are all in the warp, captured or removed from the game.
aliens.superBody: During your regroup phase, send one of your ships to the warp instead of retrieving one.

aliens.name: Micron
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Mass Numbers.
aliens.powerBody: As a main player or allly, after allies are invited, use this power. Each of your ships is worth two for encounter totals, compenstatio, and rewards for the remainder of the encounter.
aliens.history: Starting life on a diminutive planet, the Microns imagined themselves to be enormous beings compared to their local flora and fauna. Undaunted by discovering that they were much smaller than galactic standards, this has not impeded their desire for universal dominance. The Microns fill their vessels with countless souls to overwhelm any planet they happen upon.
aliens.wildBody: As the offense or an ally, you can send a number of ships up to the number of your home and foreign colonies.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power, each of your ships is worth 3 (instead of 2).

aliens.name: Perfectionist
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Idealism.
aliens.powerBody:
Once per encounter, when you add any cards to your hand, you may use this power to place any of those cards facedown on this sheet in a reject pile. You may also use this power when you are dealt a starting hand.

When another power would take cards from your hand at random, you may use this power to force that player to take some or all of them at random from your reject pile instead.

You may offer cards from your hand.
aliens.history: Generations of research has led to a 99.8% rejection of inferior goods. With a chortle and a flick, the Perfectionists now swipe their way to mastery of all things Cosmic, keeping only the best for themselves and consigning the worst to the rest.
aliens.wildBody: After you gain a card as a reward or compensation, set it aside facedown and gain another in the same way. Then, the set-aside card is discarded or returned to the other player, as appropriate.
aliens.superBody: When you use your power to place cards on this sheet, gain cards from the same source equal to the number of cards that you placed. You may use your power on these cards as well, but if you do, do not resolve this effect for those placed cards.

aliens.name: Sadist
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Cruelty.
aliens.powerBody: When another player has at least eight ships in the warp, captured and/or out of the game, place a token under that player's colony marker. At the end of the resolution phase, if all other players have a token under their colony marker, use this power to win the game. You may still win the game via the normal manner. As a main player or ally, after your side wins the encounter, if any players on the other side would lose fewer than three ships to the warp, use this power to force each of those players to lose one additional ship to the warp.
aliens.history: A civilization that glorifies inflicting pain in excessively brutal rituals, the Sadists barely managed to survive to their space-faring age. Desiring to spread their unique form of worship across the many realms of space and time, these beings enter the Cosmos with an eager eye for torment and a mind full of cruel creativity.
aliens.wildBody: As a main player, after winning the encounter, for each player that was on the opposing side, draw one card from the deck.
aliens.superBody: When using your power to force players to lose one ship, they must lose two ships instead.

aliens.name: Schizoid
aliens.gameSetup: Choose one condition card from your essence card set and place it facedown on this sheet. Shuffle the remaining seven condition cards as a deck and place them facedown near this sheet. Ignore normal essence card rules.
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Shift Reality.
aliens.powerBody:
As a main player, after you lose an encounter or fail to make a deal, the opposing main player draws a card at random from your condition deck and places it faceup on this sheet.

When any player(s) would win by the normal (not alternate) victory conditions, use this power to prevent that win. When any player(s) would win by one of your conditions (faceup or facedown), use this power to declare them the winner(s).
aliens.history: As the Schizoids slip between cascading alternative spacetimes, their mere presence shifts the reality of other creatures around them.
aliens.wildBody: If you are not using the Double Aliens variant, add it and draw and resolve a selection card, replacing any drawn aliens with Game Setup text. Each player gains the alien they required. Then, give this card to the Schizoid, or remove it from the game if the Schizoid is not playing.
aliens.superBody: As the offense, at the end of the encounter, choose a condition from your essence set and swap it with the condition card on your sheet, only if no player fulfills its condition.

aliens.name: Void
aliens.powerName: You have the power to Absorb.
aliens.powerBody:
As a winning main player or ally, use this power. All ships that would be sent to the warp during resolution are captured and placed on this sheet instead.

You may send a player's ships from this sheet to the warp as part of a deal.

If this sheet is turned facedown, all ships on it remain. If this sheet is removed from the game, send all ships on it to the warp.
aliens.history: For countless eons, the Void conflated abiogenesis and spontaneous generation so they are deeply offended at the notion that aliens exists. Although only some Void even tolerate the belief that there is life, those that do seek to cleanse the heavens of all beings, coporeal or otherwise.
aliens.wildBody: Send one of your ships not in the encounter to the warp to cancel an artifact card. This is not treated as a card zap. The artifact card is discarded.
aliens.superBody: After you use yourpower, each player from whoom you captured ships must choose one of their ships on one of their colonies. Capture the chosen ship(s) as well.

aliens.name: Zombie
aliens.short: Ships Never Stay in the Warp
aliens.powerName: You have the power of Reanimation.
aliens.powerBody: During each regroup phase, use this power to free all of your ships in the warp, sending them to one  of your home planets (including a planet without a home colony.)  Additionallly, you may free any number of another player's shps from the warp as part of a deal with that player.
aliens.history: Goeey entities from cold and dreary worlds, Zombies had tapped all sources of energy from their original home planets. They continued only by carefully recycling their own kind. "Living" on decomposing matter, they detest the unnecessary wastes of ware and have developed morally dubious methods to ensure their numbers will never permanently be reduced.
aliens.wildBody: As part of a deal, you may free any number of your opponent's ships from the warp.
aliens.superBody: After a player agrees to ally with you, instead of sending ships from their colonies, they may send any number of their ships from the warp. This can allow them to be above their normal ship limit.
